fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In the previous section, we discussed algorithms that minimize turnaround time OR response time. Here, we will look at how to find a happy middle ground

The main idea is to maintain multiple queues with varying levels of priority. Each queue will then be scheduled round-robin within priority groups and lower priorities will not be scheduled until all processes of higher priority are completed. This introduces a few problems that we must remedy

One approach is the idea of allotment. Essentially, each process is given an alloted amount of time at each priority. Once the process has run for the alloted amount of time at a given priority it moves down to the next priority.

Clearly, this achieves a good response time because it essentially reduces to round robin. This also does not tank performance because, if we recall that STCF is the optimal algorithm for turnaround time, we see that short jobs will still finish relatively quickly because they will spend all of their time at high priority (assuming a high enough allotment).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We also saw in the previous section that one way to handle I/O is by breaking it into multiple jobs. However, this can result in gaming an allotment scheduler by I/O-ing right before you reach allotment essentially ensuring your process always remains the highest priority. To deal with this, we can count the total time spent by each of the jobs toward the allotment.

html:div.html:em: How do we prevent starvation of lower priority queues?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: It seems the easiest way for this is to just periodically move all processes back to the highest priority.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
The key idea here is rather than maintain queues of priorities we instead assign each job a certain proportion of the CPU time. The obvious question:
How do we ensure the jobs actually match the desired proportion?
The first approach is the concept of ticket currency. The idea is to give each user a finite amount of tickets and have them allocate them amongs their processes.
2025726Remark They also allow ticket transfer and ticket inflation, where a process can transfer tickets i.e. client / server, or temporarily increase their number of tickets.
2025726Remark The benefit of the ticket currency approach is the simplicity of the implementation. You simply draw a random number in the range of the total number of tickets and select the process with that number.
2025726Remark The natural question of how to actually assign tickets is very difficult and not solved.
Deterministic version: The ambitious observer might wonder if there is a deterministic algorithm to achieve the same effect. Luckily, the answer is actually yes! Rather than randomly sample tickets, we set the stride to be inversely proportional to the ticket count. We then track the pass (a running sum for each process that is incremented by the processes stride). To formalize-ish,
Choose process with lowest pass.
Increment the chosen process pass by the process stride.
Repeat. We see that a low stride (high ticket count) results in being scheduled more frequently.
2025726Remark There is still an advantage of lottery-based scheduling: no global state. If new processes join, it is unclear what to set their initial pass at.
2025726Remark On linux, the user can manually set priorities using nice and setting the niceness of a process in [-20, 20).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Toward the end of the previous section we alluded to the ominuous entity known as the scheduler. There is only one question that needs answering

html:div.html:em: How should we pick what process to run at any given time?

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
It turns out there is no right answer to this question (at least that is my takeaway from these three sections in the book). The reason for this is the conflicting priorities of various metrics. Namely,
turnaround time: the time to complete a process i.e. T_{\text {completion}} - T_{\text {arrival}}
fairness: this is computed according to some arbitrary index. However, the main idea is that worst case jobs should not be neglected
response time: how long it takes from issuing the command to it being scheduled.

FIFO: A naive and fair scheduler is to just serve each job in a first-in-first-out manner. However this suffers from the convoy effect. Namely, if we consider the case where the first job is very long. Then subsequent much shorter jobs will have much longer service times than they should.

SJF: To counteract this, we can try the shortest job first. If all jobs arrive at the same time, then SJF actually provably minimizes turnaround time. However, all jobs do not arrive at the same time and if the same problematic sequence for FIFO arrives sequentially it will also break SJF.

STCF: Up to this point, we have assumed that all jobs must be run to completion. However, we can relax this assumption and allow the OS to preempt a job (pausing it and starting a new job). With this, we introduce shortest to completion first, where we periodically preempt the current running job and then schedule the job with the shortest amount of time remaining until completion.

RR: While the previous algorithm is optimal with respect to turnaround time, it is not very good with respect to response time. In particular, long jobs may not be serviced for a very long time. The best we can do with respect to response time is just round robin, where we periodically randomly switch between processes. The intervals between switching are referred to as strides or time slices or quantum lengths.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Each time we switch between processes, we incur the cost of a context switch. Choosing larger time slices allows us to amortize this cost.

Prior to this, we had been ignoring I/O of the processes. A very simple way to not suffer substantial performance loss due to I/O is to simply divide the process up into its non I/O components and schedule them individually.

html:ol.html:li: For what types of workloads does SJF deliver the same turnaround as FIFO?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For workloads that arrive in increasing order of total job time.

html:ol.html:li: For what types of workloads and quantum lengths does SJF deliver the same response times as RR?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For shorter jobs and longer quantum lengths, RR and SJF should deliver similar response times.

html:ol.html:li: What happens to response time with SJF as job lengths increase?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Response time degrades because the longest jobs have to wait for each of the shorter jobs to finish. If these shorter jobs become longer than the response time grows linearly(?).

html:ol.html:li: What happens to response time with RR as quantum lengths increase? Can you write an equation that gives the worst-case response time, given N jobs?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The response time is the average over stride length number of preceding jobs. The formula can be written as \mathrm {RT} = \frac {1}{N} \sum _{i = 1}^{N} (i - 1)S = \frac {S(N - 1) N}{N} = S(N - 1)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (7/66)
The contents of this chapter were revolved around two fundamental questions:

html:li.html:em: How do we make sure a program doesn't do what we don't want it to do?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the first question, we introduce two modes user mode and kernel mode. In user mode, we are restricted with what sort of operations we can run.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: More importantly, in user mode, we are limited with what we can see. We will see later on in memory, but in user mode we have a limited address space allocated for the current process. However, in kernel mode, the address space is the entire computer and can therefore be very dangerous if we are not careful.
How do we switch from user and kernel mode without allowing processes to run instructions in kernel mode?
We must have some cooperation from the hardware. Namely, on boot, the OS code is run and sets up a trap table.

The hardware has some responsibility when switching to kernel mode. Namely, it must store two types of registers (1) user registers (2) kernel register.
The user registers are registers that contain the current program context i.e. stack variables, such as x = 1.
The kernel registers hold more meta-information, such as the PC, the syscall number of the calling syscall, etc.
Kellen Kanarios2025719Remark Each time we return to a process or switch between processes the hardware must perform a context switch. This is when they store all of the context of the current program before replacing it with the context of another program. The cost of such a switch is the tradeoff when performing scheduling of processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In order to implement the syscall, there needs to be some pre-agreed upon arrangement on where certain things go. For example, the syscall number must be stored in a pre-defined register. The general procedure (I think?) is as follows:

html:ol.html:li: syscall calls trap instruction defined by hardware.
hardware stores all information necessary to restore processes in pre-determined location.
hardware switches to kernel mode from user mode.
hardware jumps to code in OS to handle syscall (trap handler / interrupt handler?).
OS code checks pre-arranged register for the syscall number
OS executes corresponding syscall code.
OS restores program.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Due to relying on pre-determined registers, the syscalls are typically hand coded in assembly.
The OS must also perform checks regarding the safety of the requested operation i.e. we cannot let a process read the kernel code...
There is a similar mechanism for interrupts via an interrupt handler.
If the CPU is running a process, then how can the kernel decide to stop running it?
It can't... Instead the hardware performs period interrupts that trap to the OS code. The OS code can then decide what process to run via the scheduler (next section).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This section is a summary of my findings:

html:ol.html:li: Power signals reset of CPU state.
CPU runs BIOS, which checks that hardware works.
BIOS then runs bootloader (i.e. grub).
Bootloader places kernel code in right place and runs it.
Kernel then specifies things like trap table location (which is a special hardware instruction). Also must set timer.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Part of my revisiting CS fundamentals journey
Deliberate-Practice (1/66)

A process consists of a few primary components
Memory: each process requires its own portion of memory for (i) to store the instructions of the program to execute and (ii) for the memory required by the calling program. This is referred to as the address space.
Registers: for those familiar with computers, instructions typically deal with registers, where information is loaded from memory into registers to perform computation. Additionally, there are special registers reserved for certain mechanisms i.e.
Program Counter (PC): This register is in charge of telling us what instruction we are currently on in the executing program.
Stack and Frame Pointer: Used to manage where we currently are on the stack.
In order to implement a process, one must support each of the following operations

html:li.html:p: The operating system must implement a mechanism to create a process. This consists of loading the program from disk, initializing memory (i.e. stack and heap), and jumping to main (typically).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The stack is allocated up front and does not change. However, typically a small amount of memory is allocated for the heap and it grows via malloc. This is non-trivial because if malloc is called without available heap memory then memory must be allocated by the OS. I need to look into how this is done more.
The OS will also initialize the parameters to main i.e. argc or argv.

html:ol.html:li: Destroy: Clearly, if a process is misbehaved or the user just does not want it to run any longer, there must be some mechanism to kill the process.
Wait: In the case of dependencies (piping?), it may be useful to wait for a process to complete.
Miscellaneous Control: The example provided in the book is to suspend a process.
Status: It is helpful to be able to get information about running processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There are also process states. These states are running, ready, and blocked. These states are pretty self-explanatory.
It seems throughout the book we will be seeing implementation examples from the smaller xv6 OS.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In addition to the process implementation below, there is also a data structure that must keep track of all the processes. This is the process list or process control block.

html:ol.html:li:
Run process.py with the flags -l 5:100, 5:100. What should the CPU utilization be?
Kellen Kanarios2025623AnswerThe flags correspond to running two processes each with 5 instructions where each instruction has probability one of using the CPU. The output from the program is Process 0 cpu cpu cpu cpu cpu
Process 1 cpu cpu cpu cpu cpu with this, we can conclude that the utilization is 100%. We will execute one instruction for the first process until it completes, then the five instructions of the next process. If both are waiting on IO, then I do not think this would be the case?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution Using the solution flags -cp, there is 100% utilization.

Run process.py with the flags -l 4:100, 1:0. How long does it take to complete both processes?
Kellen Kanarios2025623AnswerThe flags correspond to running one process with 4 instructions with each instruction having probability one of using the CPU and one process with one instruction that uses the IO. The output from the program is Process 0 cpu cpu cpu cpu
Process 1 io io_done It will take 4 + \text {time of IO}. Since the process with 4 non-IO-dependent instructions will run each of those instructions and then the next process will begin which must wait for the entire duration of IO.
Kellen Kanarios2025623SolutionUsing the -cp flags it takes 11 timesteps to complete which is \approx 4 + \text {time of IO}.

Now switch the order of the processes: ./process-run.py -l 1:0,4:100. What happens now? Does switching the order mat- ter? Why?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The output of the code is Process 0 io io_done
Process 1 cpu cpu cpu cpu Depending on the time of IO (the -L flag), it should take \max (5, 1 + \text {time IO}). Switching the order does matter because we can run the CPU instructions while waiting for non-blocking IO. This motivates the idea of scheduling.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution It only takes 7 timesteps because we are able to perform the IO operations off the CPU as expected.

Weâ€™ll now explore some of the other flags. One important flag is -S, which determines how the system reacts when a process issues an I/O. With the flag set to SWITCH_ON_END, the system will NOT switch to another process while one is doing I/O, instead waiting until the process is completely finished. What happens when you run the following two processes, one doing I/O and the other doing CPU work? (-l 1:0,4:100 -c -S SWITCH_ON_END)
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The output of the code is: Time PID: 0 PID: 1 CPU IOs 1 RUN:io READY 1 2 BLOCKED READY 1 3 BLOCKED READY 1 4 BLOCKED READY 1 5 BLOCKED READY 1 6 BLOCKED READY 1 7* RUN:io_done READY 1 8 DONE RUN:cpu 1 9 DONE RUN:cpu 1 10 DONE RUN:cpu 1 11 DONE RUN:cpu 1 As expected, it runs the IO process, blocking the CPU process until it is completed.

Now, run the same processes, but with the switching behavior set to switch to another process whenever one is WAITING for I/O (-l 1:0,4:100 -c -S SWITCH ON IO). What happens now? Use -c and -p to confirm that you are right

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: I assume that at timestep 1 we will still RUN:io. However, we will then switch the PID: 1 for the next 4 timesteps until it is completed. After one additional BLOCKED timestep, we will run RUN:io_done and complete both processes.
The output of the code is: Time PID: 0 PID: 1 CPU IOs 1 RUN:io READY 1 2 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 3 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 4 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 5 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 6 BLOCKED DONE 1 7* RUN:io_done DONE 1

html:ol.html:li:
One other important behavior is what to do when an I/O completes. With -I IO RUN LATER, when an I/O completes, the process that issued it is not necessarily run right away; rather, whatever was running at the time keeps running. What happens when you run this combination of processes? (./process-run.py -l 3:0,5:100,5:100,5:100 -S SWITCH ON IO -I IO RUN LATER -c -p) Are system resources being effectively utilized?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The resources are not efficiently utilized because we end up waiting until all of our CPU-bound processes finish before returning to the IO-bound process, which calls another IO:run and we do not get any concurrency benefit.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution The code output is pretty long but the end output is Stats: Total Time 31 Stats: CPU Busy 21 (67.74%) Stats: IO Busy 15 (48.39%)

Now run the same processes, but with -I IO RUN IMMEDIATE set, which immediately runs the process that issued the I/O. How does this behavior differ? Why might running a process that just completed an I/O again be a good idea?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The behavior differs by returning to the IO-bound process, which can then immediately call the next IO:run before returning access to the CPU-bound processes, improving concurrency. In an attempt to predict the next IO call, it might be a good idea to run the process that just completed IO because it is more likely to make another IO call.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution The corresponding statistics are Stats: Total Time 21 Stats: CPU Busy 21 (100.00%) Stats: IO Busy 15 (71.43%)

Now run with some randomly generated processes, e.g., -s 1 -l 3:50,3:50, -s 2 -l 3:50,3:50, -s 3 -l 3:50,3:50. See if you can predict how the trace will turn out. What happens when you use -I IO RUN IMMEDIATE vs. -I IO RUN LATER? What hap- pens when you use -S SWITCH ON IO vs. -S SWITCH ON END?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer Since each instruction has a 50% chance of being CPU or I/O, I do not think there will be much benefit to IO_RUN_LATER vs. IO_RUN_IMMEDIATE. However, I believe it will be crucial to enable -S SWITCH_ON_IO over -S SWITCH_ON_END as the number of processes grow because we should always have waiting CPU instructions to run. In the case of two processes, we still may not improve that much because they will likely both be IO-bound at some point.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution For -s 1 (aka the seed), the observed performance between IO_RUN_IMMEDIATE and IO_RUN_LATER is the same. However, we do observe an improvement on both IO and CPU usage when we enable SWITCH_ON_IO.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (3/66)
This was a very short chapter just introducing the actual API for some very important system calls. Namely

The fork system call allows a program to duplicate itself in a new process from the current instruction. This is quite literally a duplication which entails giving the child its own
Address space
Registers
Program counter
Importantly, you identify whether you are in the child or the parent via the return value of rc (0 for child), (PID of child for parent).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Which process is run first (the parent or the child) is non-deterministic and depends on the CPU scheduling algorithm.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Due to the remark, we need some way to enforce ordering among parent and child. This is the motivation for the wait system call. Namely, when the parent calls wait() it tells the CPU not to schedule it until the child completes.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: From the previous section, we saw the data structure for a process included the state. I assume wait() is implemented by adjusting the process state in the PCB somehow?

Doing a bit more research, it seems this is on the right track. Additionally, when a child completes it enters the ZOMBIE state, where it stores all the relevant information of the process, so that the parent process can then use this information. How this is actually coordinated seems to involve signals and wait_entries that essentially track all the children of a parent. The OS can then get a signal of completion from a child and find the corresponding parent?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: While fork() is useful in the sense that it allows us to spawn new processes from a parent process, it is still limited in that it can only execute instructions following the line of the fork() call in the parent process.

They briefly mention signals: what I expect to be an important topic in the future. Namely, you can send a signall to a process via kill() and the recipient program can "catch" this signal via the system call signal().
This naturally leads to the introduction of a user. The user determines which processes they are allowed to signal, where the superuser can arbitrarily signal all processes.
Deliberate-Practice (6/66).

html:ol.html:li: Write a program that calls fork(). Before calling fork(), have the main process access a variable (e.g., x) and set its value to something (e.g., 100). What value is the variable in the child process? What happens to the variable when both the child and parent change the value of x

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Both the parent and the child get a copy of the variable values i.e. x. When they modify x it only affects the copy of x in their local address space.

html:ol.html:li: Write a program that opens a file (with the open() system call) and then calls fork() to create a new process. Can both the child and parent access the file descriptor returned by open()? What happens when they are writing to the file concurrently, i.e., at the same time?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Both do have access to the same file descriptor. I believe that they can interleave writes if writing at the same time but for me whichever process got ran first always finished writing prior the other starting. This may be a scheduling thing, where one process is able to complete before the other is scheduled?

html:ol.html:li: Write another program using fork(). The child process should print â€œhelloâ€; the parent process should print â€œgoodbyeâ€. You should try to ensure that the child process always prints first; can you do this without calling wait() in the parent?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Using the previous problem, in the child, we can write something to a file. Then, in the parent, we can enforce an ordering by making the parent wait in a while loop until it reads the value written by the child. However, this is terribly inconvenient (and probably why wait() exists).

html:ol.html:li: Now write a program that uses wait() to wait for the child process to finish in the parent. What does wait() return? What happens if you use wait() in the child?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: wait() returns the pid of the child process that died. Using wait() in the child just immediately returns -1.

html:ol.html:li: Write a program that calls fork() and then calls some form of exec() to run the program /bin/ls. See if you can try all of the variants of exec(), including execl(), execle(), execlp(), execv(), execvp(), and execvP(). Why do you think there are so many variants of the same basic call?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It seems that some of them support different types of arguments i.e. execv family allows variable size argument list. Additionally, there is a distinction in the environment. This seems to be a list of environment variable values that exec{l,v}e() will search over. The p family use the same search as the shell i.e. the PATH.

html:ol.html:li: Write a slight modification of the previous program, this time us- ing waitpid() instead of wait(). When would waitpid() be useful?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If a parent process has multiple children, then wait() will only wait until the first one dies. waitpid() lets you specify waiting on a specific child process.

html:ol.html:li: Write a program that creates a child process, and then in the child closes standard output (STDOUT_FILENO). What happens if the child calls printf() to print some output after closing the descriptor?

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Nothing prints in the child process. However, stdout is still open in the parent process and able to print.

html:ol.html:li: Write a program that creates two children, and connects the standard output of one to the standard input of the other, using the pipe() system call

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This required fflush() for me. I am not sure if this is true in general?

The key idea here is rather than maintain queues of priorities we instead assign each job a certain proportion of the CPU time. The obvious question:
How do we ensure the jobs actually match the desired proportion?
The first approach is the concept of ticket currency. The idea is to give each user a finite amount of tickets and have them allocate them amongs their processes.
2025726Remark They also allow ticket transfer and ticket inflation, where a process can transfer tickets i.e. client / server, or temporarily increase their number of tickets.
2025726Remark The benefit of the ticket currency approach is the simplicity of the implementation. You simply draw a random number in the range of the total number of tickets and select the process with that number.
2025726Remark The natural question of how to actually assign tickets is very difficult and not solved.
Deterministic version: The ambitious observer might wonder if there is a deterministic algorithm to achieve the same effect. Luckily, the answer is actually yes! Rather than randomly sample tickets, we set the stride to be inversely proportional to the ticket count. We then track the pass (a running sum for each process that is incremented by the processes stride). To formalize-ish,
Choose process with lowest pass.
Increment the chosen process pass by the process stride.
Repeat. We see that a low stride (high ticket count) results in being scheduled more frequently.
2025726Remark There is still an advantage of lottery-based scheduling: no global state. If new processes join, it is unclear what to set their initial pass at.
2025726Remark On linux, the user can manually set priorities using nice and setting the niceness of a process in [-20, 20).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We are now moving on from scheduling into the wonderful world of all things memory.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
If we think about what we have done so far, we have an assortment of processes that are constantly being switched between. However, each of these process has their own assortment of register states, but more importantly they each have their own state in memory.
For register states, the OS has its own reserved memory, where it can easily store and switch between register states.
For memory, when we switch processes, are we expected to clear out memory for the next process by storing to disk? NO! This motivates the idea behind address spaces. Namely, each process is given its own address space (chunk in memory) to use at its own discretion. This will then ensure that other processes do not overwrite the program state of one another. The address space of a process typically consists of three components
Code of the program
Stack: local var, arguments, return values
Heap: dynamically allocated memory
2025729Remark As we will see later, every address we see is actually virtual, meaning it is not the location in physical memory.
API: We only really need two methods, a way to get memory and a way to release memory. These are implemented via malloc and free. However, the use of these is usually accompanied with a handful of common errors:
Forget to initialize mem.
Forget to free mem.
Freeing memory early: dangling pointer.
Freeing the same memory twice: double free.
Passing something not allocated earlier: invalid free.
2025729Remark When a process dies, the OS reclaims all of that process memory. This means that as long as your program memory is bounded, leakage will not do any sort of catastrophic damage. However, it is still not good practice.
2025729Remark malloc and free are not syscalls. The heap is pre-allocated with some allotment of memory. If the program exceeds this memory then malloc will call a syscall brk / sbrk to increment / decrement heap mem pointer.
2025729Remark You can actually initialize and use your own heap-like memory through mmap. This memory is not associated with any particular file and is an anonymous memory region within your program.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The next question is once each program has their own address space, how do we unify the experience for the user.

html:ol.html:li: We want every process to have the illusion that is starts at address 0
We want every process to have the illusion of a large address space.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: However, we also do not want to give up the protection / speed of the address space abstraction. The overarching idea is virualizing the address space. This means that the address the user sees is not the true address in physical memory. How we achieve this will be a longstanding topic for the next few entries of these notes.

Base and Bounds: The first approach is base and bounds. For this approach, the hardware has a dedicated base and bound register to indicate where the address space for a given process begins and ends. It is the OSes job to ensure that these registers are filled with the correct values for the current process.
The hardware must provide protected instructions to allow the OS to modify the base and bound registers.

An address translation is then performed by the hardware by adding the base to the virtual address and checking it remains within the bounds. This is done by the memory management unit (MMU). A common theme we will see is that hardware support is crucial to achieve good virtualization.

html:div.html:em: to support a large addres space with base and bounds we suffer significant internal fragmentation i.e. in between the base and bound there is a lot of unused memory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To better understand why fragmentation is such an issue: if we have 16kb total memory and each process requests 4kb but only uses 2kb, then we can only maintain 4 processes despite having the memory to service 8! To attempt to remedy this, we will introduce the idea of segmentation.

Instead of pre-allocating the memory between the heap and stack, why don't we allocate on demand. To do so, we can treat the code, heap, and stack as their own segments with their own base and bound registers. An address could then be decomposed as \underbrace {0 1}_{\text {segment}}\underbrace {0 1 \cdots 11}_{\text {offset}} This also enables an idea of memory sharing, where process can share a portion of memory (such as the code) to save memory on the system.
Need to add a protection bit to indicate whether a process can modify certain addrs.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This limits flexibility in the sense that we have no control over where the middle region was allocated and therefore we cannot grow beyond the initial bound.
The hardware also has to support the stack growing backwards when it checks the bounds. To do so, it has to perform an additional check based on the segment number.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
We have been talking a lot about how to abstract physical address to provide ease of use for the programmer. However, we have yet to discuss how to actually allocate these physical addresses in the first place. When allocating memory, there are a few issues we need to be careful about
External fragmentation: lots of small unallocated non-contiguous chunks of memory.
Internal fragmentation: allocated memory that is unused in the process it is allocated for. To start, we make a few simplifying assumptions:
After memory has been allocated, it cannot be moved.
The size of memory is fixed.
The user does not specify the size in free. First, we can quickly deal with the last problem by introducing a header. The OS stores additional metadata, such as the size of the allocated memory in a header directly preceding the returned pointer in memory.
If int* x = malloc(sizeof(int)) then header = (header_t)* x - 1.
OS needs to find memory for the requested memory + size of the header.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
The general allocation algorithm consists of maintaining some free-list that contains the address and length of free memory. An allocation is done by some policy over this list. When memory is re-claimed, the list is searched for adjacent memory and if it is found then it is coalesced into a larger chunk of free memory.
Best fit: find smallest chunk that is big enough
leaves lots of small chunks
Worst fit: find largest chunk Both of these require searching the entire list, so instead we can introduce some heuristics.
First fit: find first block that can service.
Next fit: find first block that can service starting from the previous allocation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Outside of the allocation policy, we can make data-structure level optimization. One such optimization is segmentation lists. The idea is to maintain different lists that correspond to different commonly allocated object types.

html:ul.html:li: Grow list by requesting segments as multiple size of the objects.
Can return to main list when no references.
Can also leave objects pre-iitialized on list to eliminate calls to constructor / destructor.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Assume memory is size 2^n. Search through memory to find smallest block that can service request.

When block is freed,
Check if the buddy is free.
If the buddy is free.
Coalesce into larger block
Repeat. Can easily check buddy because address differ by one bit at each level. Just modify the corresponding bit and check the free data structure (bitmap?) if the address is free. If it is then move up and check the next bit.

Previously, we have only dealt with memory allocations as variable sized chunks i.e. the amount of memory allocated can be anything. A simple idea to avoid the drastic fragmentation this can induce is to instead divide memory into fixed size chunks. This idea is called paging, where each chunk is a page.

html:div.html:em: how do we virtualize memory with pages?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Problem 1: The page table can get ridiculously large.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For now, we consider a linear page table (an array with entry for each VPN). If we support a 32 bit address space with 4kb pages and each entry in the page table is 4 bytes then this is 2^{32} / 2^{12} * 4 = 2^{22} bytes of memory for the page table!

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Before, we relied on the MMU to translate between physical and virtual addresses via simple operations like base and bound. However, there is no way the MMU could support this many arbitrary translations. Therefore, the page table itself must be stored in physical memory.

In addition to the address translation, the page table also keeps track of the following bits:
Valid bit: whether this particular VPN has memory allocated to it i.e. mem between stack / heap does not need to be allocated.
Protection bit: determines whether the calling program can read / write / execute.
Present bit: whether the page currently resides in physical memory.
Dirty bit: has the page been modified since being paged in.
Reference bit: has the page been accessed (used for eviction policy).

Problem 2: Every time we want to perform an address translation (very often) we must
Compute VPN from address
Access page table entry in physical memory (slow)
Compute address with offset + PPN.
Access corresponding physical page in physical memory. This is very slow!
Due to the previously discussed issues, we need a faster way of performing address translation to make paging a feasible option. A common theme: we will throw hardware at it

Specifically, we will add an additional cache known as the translation lookaside buffer that caches address translations. Generally, an address translation proceeds as:
Extract VPN
Check if VPN in TLB
If in TLB: get translation
Otherwise: TLB miss -> trap to OS (RISC)

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have to be a little careful. The OS code itself is located in memory and is therefore subject to our paging system. We can imagine that on TLB miss the hardware tries to load the TLB miss handler code by checking the TLB, getting the translation, and loading the code. But what if the translation for the TLB miss handler is not in the TLB?!?! To not worry about these things the TLB miss handler gets a permanent spot in physical memory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Formally, an entry in the TLB consists of
VPN
PPN
Other bits
Valid bit: has valid translation (different from PTE valid bit) can be invalid on initialization, eviction, or context switch.
Protection bit: whether the requested access can be performed.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Each process has different address translations corresponding to the same VPN.
Keep additional address space identifier (ASID) in TLB entry. We also need an ASID register that we set at every process switch to identify the current running process.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: "Ram is not always ram". Referring to the fact that a physical memory access takes a substantial different amount of time depending on whether it hit in the TLB.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
In a real software managed TLB, the TLB consisted of the following components:
Global bits for globally shared pages,
8 bit ASID,
Coherence bits for cache-coherence,
32-64 TLB entries,
A wired register to indicate how many slots to reserve in the TLB for things like TLB miss handler.

Another important tidbit: when using very fast caches, even an access to the TLB is a CPU bottleneck (accessing TLB is longer than accessing cache). To get around this, there are virtually indexed caches that circumvent the need for performing an address translation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: As previously discussed, as it currently stands, the page table takes up too much memory.
Solution 1: Just use bigger pages! Unfortunately, this will suffer from severe internal fragmentation (processes not using their allocated memory) and so we would prefer to avoid this solution.

Solution 2: Paging + segmentation. Instead of a page table for all of memory, keep 3 page tables: one for code, stack, and heap. This only partially resolves the problem.
Same problems as segmentation. Variable sized page tables will cause external fragmentation
We can do better. Within each heap, there is still a (smaller) version of the same problem: a bunch of unused allocated PTEs.
Multi-level page tables: Finally, we have arrived to the idea of a multi-level page table. The idea can be summarized as

html:ol.html:li: Chop page table up into pages.
Do not allocated pages with no valid references (i.e. none of the corresponding are being used).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This has a few advantages:

html:ol.html:li: Fits easily in memory. Allocate one page when an entry is used.
Proportional to the amount of address space actually in use.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The obvious downside is the added complexity. Namely, on every TLB miss we must make two loads of memory (1) the page directory entry and (2) the page table entry.

fr:title.text: What happens when memory is full?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: What happens when memory is full?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We reserve space on disk for pages that cannot fit in physical memory. This is referred to as swap space.

We need to add an additional present bit to the PTE. On a TLB miss, the hardware (or software) will check the page table and see the present bit to indicate whether the page is in physical memory. If not, we must trap to the OS and this is known as a page fault.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The hardware never handles page faults because this would require understanding swap space + knowing how to perform I/O with disk.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Three important cases to consider:

html:ol.html:li: Page is present and valid.

html:ul.html:li: Hardware can just grab physical address from PTE.

html:ol.html:li: Page is not present but valid.

html:ul.html:li: Hardware must call page fault handler to retrieve page.

html:ol.html:li: Page is not valid.

html:ul.html:li: Throw exception and likely terminate process as it is accessing invalid memory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (3/66)
This was a very short chapter just introducing the actual API for some very important system calls. Namely

The fork system call allows a program to duplicate itself in a new process from the current instruction. This is quite literally a duplication which entails giving the child its own
Address space
Registers
Program counter
Importantly, you identify whether you are in the child or the parent via the return value of rc (0 for child), (PID of child for parent).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Which process is run first (the parent or the child) is non-deterministic and depends on the CPU scheduling algorithm.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Due to the remark, we need some way to enforce ordering among parent and child. This is the motivation for the wait system call. Namely, when the parent calls wait() it tells the CPU not to schedule it until the child completes.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: From the previous section, we saw the data structure for a process included the state. I assume wait() is implemented by adjusting the process state in the PCB somehow?

Doing a bit more research, it seems this is on the right track. Additionally, when a child completes it enters the ZOMBIE state, where it stores all the relevant information of the process, so that the parent process can then use this information. How this is actually coordinated seems to involve signals and wait_entries that essentially track all the children of a parent. The OS can then get a signal of completion from a child and find the corresponding parent?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: While fork() is useful in the sense that it allows us to spawn new processes from a parent process, it is still limited in that it can only execute instructions following the line of the fork() call in the parent process.

They briefly mention signals: what I expect to be an important topic in the future. Namely, you can send a signall to a process via kill() and the recipient program can "catch" this signal via the system call signal().
This naturally leads to the introduction of a user. The user determines which processes they are allowed to signal, where the superuser can arbitrarily signal all processes.

However, this is terribly inconvenient (and probably why wait() exists).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (1/66)

A process consists of a few primary components
Memory: each process requires its own portion of memory for (i) to store the instructions of the program to execute and (ii) for the memory required by the calling program. This is referred to as the address space.
Registers: for those familiar with computers, instructions typically deal with registers, where information is loaded from memory into registers to perform computation. Additionally, there are special registers reserved for certain mechanisms i.e.
Program Counter (PC): This register is in charge of telling us what instruction we are currently on in the executing program.
Stack and Frame Pointer: Used to manage where we currently are on the stack.
In order to implement a process, one must support each of the following operations

html:li.html:p: The operating system must implement a mechanism to create a process. This consists of loading the program from disk, initializing memory (i.e. stack and heap), and jumping to main (typically).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The stack is allocated up front and does not change. However, typically a small amount of memory is allocated for the heap and it grows via malloc. This is non-trivial because if malloc is called without available heap memory then memory must be allocated by the OS. I need to look into how this is done more.
The OS will also initialize the parameters to main i.e. argc or argv.

html:ol.html:li: Destroy: Clearly, if a process is misbehaved or the user just does not want it to run any longer, there must be some mechanism to kill the process.
Wait: In the case of dependencies (piping?), it may be useful to wait for a process to complete.
Miscellaneous Control: The example provided in the book is to suspend a process.
Status: It is helpful to be able to get information about running processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There are also process states. These states are running, ready, and blocked. These states are pretty self-explanatory.
It seems throughout the book we will be seeing implementation examples from the smaller xv6 OS.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In addition to the process implementation below, there is also a data structure that must keep track of all the processes. This is the process list or process control block.

html:ol.html:li:
Run process.py with the flags -l 5:100, 5:100. What should the CPU utilization be?
Kellen Kanarios2025623AnswerThe flags correspond to running two processes each with 5 instructions where each instruction has probability one of using the CPU. The output from the program is Process 0 cpu cpu cpu cpu cpu
Process 1 cpu cpu cpu cpu cpu with this, we can conclude that the utilization is 100%. We will execute one instruction for the first process until it completes, then the five instructions of the next process. If both are waiting on IO, then I do not think this would be the case?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution Using the solution flags -cp, there is 100% utilization.

Run process.py with the flags -l 4:100, 1:0. How long does it take to complete both processes?
Kellen Kanarios2025623AnswerThe flags correspond to running one process with 4 instructions with each instruction having probability one of using the CPU and one process with one instruction that uses the IO. The output from the program is Process 0 cpu cpu cpu cpu
Process 1 io io_done It will take 4 + \text {time of IO}. Since the process with 4 non-IO-dependent instructions will run each of those instructions and then the next process will begin which must wait for the entire duration of IO.
Kellen Kanarios2025623SolutionUsing the -cp flags it takes 11 timesteps to complete which is \approx 4 + \text {time of IO}.

Now switch the order of the processes: ./process-run.py -l 1:0,4:100. What happens now? Does switching the order mat- ter? Why?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The output of the code is Process 0 io io_done
Process 1 cpu cpu cpu cpu Depending on the time of IO (the -L flag), it should take \max (5, 1 + \text {time IO}). Switching the order does matter because we can run the CPU instructions while waiting for non-blocking IO. This motivates the idea of scheduling.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution It only takes 7 timesteps because we are able to perform the IO operations off the CPU as expected.

Weâ€™ll now explore some of the other flags. One important flag is -S, which determines how the system reacts when a process issues an I/O. With the flag set to SWITCH_ON_END, the system will NOT switch to another process while one is doing I/O, instead waiting until the process is completely finished. What happens when you run the following two processes, one doing I/O and the other doing CPU work? (-l 1:0,4:100 -c -S SWITCH_ON_END)
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The output of the code is: Time PID: 0 PID: 1 CPU IOs 1 RUN:io READY 1 2 BLOCKED READY 1 3 BLOCKED READY 1 4 BLOCKED READY 1 5 BLOCKED READY 1 6 BLOCKED READY 1 7* RUN:io_done READY 1 8 DONE RUN:cpu 1 9 DONE RUN:cpu 1 10 DONE RUN:cpu 1 11 DONE RUN:cpu 1 As expected, it runs the IO process, blocking the CPU process until it is completed.

Now, run the same processes, but with the switching behavior set to switch to another process whenever one is WAITING for I/O (-l 1:0,4:100 -c -S SWITCH ON IO). What happens now? Use -c and -p to confirm that you are right

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: I assume that at timestep 1 we will still RUN:io. However, we will then switch the PID: 1 for the next 4 timesteps until it is completed. After one additional BLOCKED timestep, we will run RUN:io_done and complete both processes.
The output of the code is: Time PID: 0 PID: 1 CPU IOs 1 RUN:io READY 1 2 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 3 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 4 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 5 BLOCKED RUN:cpu 1 1 6 BLOCKED DONE 1 7* RUN:io_done DONE 1

html:ol.html:li:
One other important behavior is what to do when an I/O completes. With -I IO RUN LATER, when an I/O completes, the process that issued it is not necessarily run right away; rather, whatever was running at the time keeps running. What happens when you run this combination of processes? (./process-run.py -l 3:0,5:100,5:100,5:100 -S SWITCH ON IO -I IO RUN LATER -c -p) Are system resources being effectively utilized?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The resources are not efficiently utilized because we end up waiting until all of our CPU-bound processes finish before returning to the IO-bound process, which calls another IO:run and we do not get any concurrency benefit.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution The code output is pretty long but the end output is Stats: Total Time 31 Stats: CPU Busy 21 (67.74%) Stats: IO Busy 15 (48.39%)

Now run the same processes, but with -I IO RUN IMMEDIATE set, which immediately runs the process that issued the I/O. How does this behavior differ? Why might running a process that just completed an I/O again be a good idea?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer The behavior differs by returning to the IO-bound process, which can then immediately call the next IO:run before returning access to the CPU-bound processes, improving concurrency. In an attempt to predict the next IO call, it might be a good idea to run the process that just completed IO because it is more likely to make another IO call.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution The corresponding statistics are Stats: Total Time 21 Stats: CPU Busy 21 (100.00%) Stats: IO Busy 15 (71.43%)

Now run with some randomly generated processes, e.g., -s 1 -l 3:50,3:50, -s 2 -l 3:50,3:50, -s 3 -l 3:50,3:50. See if you can predict how the trace will turn out. What happens when you use -I IO RUN IMMEDIATE vs. -I IO RUN LATER? What hap- pens when you use -S SWITCH ON IO vs. -S SWITCH ON END?
Kellen Kanarios2025623Answer Since each instruction has a 50% chance of being CPU or I/O, I do not think there will be much benefit to IO_RUN_LATER vs. IO_RUN_IMMEDIATE. However, I believe it will be crucial to enable -S SWITCH_ON_IO over -S SWITCH_ON_END as the number of processes grow because we should always have waiting CPU instructions to run. In the case of two processes, we still may not improve that much because they will likely both be IO-bound at some point.
Kellen Kanarios2025623Solution For -s 1 (aka the seed), the observed performance between IO_RUN_IMMEDIATE and IO_RUN_LATER is the same. However, we do observe an improvement on both IO and CPU usage when we enable SWITCH_ON_IO.
